bestBHT.bht: Peter's reply in Mark 14:68 combines two distinct answers, indicating his confusion and fluctuating resolve. The various verbal differences among the Gospel accounts suggest missing information. The mention of the porch, the cock crowing twice, and Peter's denial being fuller in Mark contribute to the authenticity of the narrative. Peter's surprise and confounded state of mind caused him to disassociate from Jesus by denying any association, despite Christ's previous warning.

Henry Alford: 68.] Peter’s reply is an union of two separate answers, which form the 1st and 2nd in Matthew.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I know not, neither understand I what thou sayest—in Luke (Matthew 26:70- :), 'I know Him not.'"
Doubtless by this time his mind would be getting into a sea of commotion, and would fluctuate every moment in its resolves.
There is here a verbal difference among the Evangelists, which without some information which has been withheld, cannot be quite extricated.
Marvin Vincent: Porch (proaulion). Only here in New Testament. The vestibule, extending from the outside gate to the court.
Philip Schaff: Into the porch, or ‘forecourt,’ a different word from that used by Matthew, but referring to the same place.
And the cock crew. The first or mid-night crow.
The insertion of this detail is probably due to Peter’s own recollection.
Archibald T. Robertson: This denial is fuller in Mark, briefest in John.
Can be understood as a direct question.
Mark alone alludes to the cock crowing twice, originally (Mark 14:30), and twice in verse Mark 14:72, besides verse Mark 14:68 which is hardly genuine.
John Gill: But he denied,.... That he was with Jesus, or a disciple of his:
saying, I know not; Jesus of Nazareth: neither understand I what thou sayest..."
...being surprised and confounded at such a challenge...

...he took no notice of it, nor remembered what Christ had but a few hours before said to him: or if he did, he might hope he should not meet with another attack, or he should have more courage and strength than to deny a second time.
